Review: Loved this. Felt incredibly lived, accurate, humane, complex, and understated. A snapshot of life, and the paths not taken, with all the complications that come with that.

Movie: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes

Review: A bit too spooky for me, but I’m a scaredy cat. I was surprised though that finally a Branagh Poirot was actually good. Keeping it confined to one location helped focus it.

On a rewatch, I still had fun with it. Going in knowing what I was gonna get made it more enjoyable to watch. But I do miss the nuance and subtlety from the book. There’s a lot of choices that are made to get this to a two hour minute movie.  Characters and plots are cut and sometimes replaced (most egregious IMO is the creation of Miguel, the Hot Bad Gay Journalist Ex-Hookup, who is a poor amalgamation of four…
So worth seeing this in 70mm IMAX.

Expected to like this more than I did. In the end, I found it frequently dull — I think the relentless negativity in the central relationship (and in the characters generally) just wore its welcome for me quite quickly, resulting in a morass of sadness that never became particularly interesting outside of a few sweet/poignant moments. A lot of stylistic choices also didn’t work for me, distracting from the story when I might otherwise be engaged. The tough thing is, I can see the artistry. But I just didn’t feel it.

Look, you KNOW I love me a pair of men kissing while wearing speedos. You KNOW I love slow motion shots of a man swimming in water. You KNOW I love happy endings (in both senses of the phrase). But this did nothing for me, I’m afraid. Don’t get me wrong — the actor who plays Beyto is gorgeous, and I would happily stare into his eyes for eternity. The problem is Mike. I hate Mike with the passion of…
Okay, this is not an easy watch, but they are cute, so plus?
Hmm, didn’t quite work for me. Very colorful, frequently funny, surprisingly airless (for Gerwig). Overall had a good time, but despite the color palette, it left me a bit cold.
I’ve got that Oscar Wilde thing going on too.

Movie: Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One

Review: Watched this on a sick day, so I was shivering as they were crying.
I can finally say I’ve seen this. I watched it with a nasty sore throat, so I was sipping soothing tea while watching people fall, drown, and scream to their deaths.
